intro: Juncus laccatus, commonly known as the water rush, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to wetland environments in North America. It typically grows in marshes, swamps, and along the edges of ponds and streams, where it thrives in moist to submerged soil conditions. The plant has slender, grass-like stems that are often clustered and can reach heights of up to 1 meter. Its small, spike-like inflorescence consists of numerous tiny greenish or brownish flowers, which are wind-pollinated. Juncus laccatus plays an important ecological role by providing habitat and food for various aquatic and wetland organisms.
